Award.AwardTitle: CIF: EAGER: TeraNets: Ultra-Broadband Communication Networks in the Terahertz Band

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of the TeraNets project is to establish the theoretical foundations of ultra-broadband communication networks in the terahertz (THz) Band. New channel models for the entire THz Band will be developed. These will account for line-of-sight, non-line-of-sight and multi-path propagation and will capture the peculiarities of molecular absorption and scattering from rough surfaces. Bandwidth-adaptive modulations to exploit the distance-dependent behavior of the bandwidth at THz Band frequencies will be developed. In addition, massive MIMO transmission schemes to increase the communication distance and novel channel coding approaches to efficiently overcome channel errors at THz Band frequencies are to be investigated. Finally, novel Medium Access Control protocols for THz Band communication networks are proposed, which capture the peculiarities of the physical layer and take advantage of large antenna arrays and dielectric mirrors.

The TeraNets project is expected to pave the way for research in communication networks in the THz Band. Ultra-broadband communication networks will play a major role in society within the next ten years by drastically increasing the capacity of wireless networks, and enabling long-awaited applications not possible with current wireless technologies. In addition, the THz Band is not yet regulated. The project team is actively involved in IEEE 802.15 WPAN Terahertz Interest Group (IGThz), whose objective is to create the first standard for this paradigm. The research results will be incorporated into the Information and Network Theory and Wireless Communication and Networks within the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, at the Georgia Institute of Technology, both at undergraduate and graduate levels. This, combined with grauate student resarch mentoring, will produce new experts in this nascent field. The research results will be disseminated in important scientific conferences, journals and premier magazines of the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, wireless data traffic has exponentially grown due to a change in the way today’s society creates, shares and consumes information. This change has been accompanied by an increasing demand for higher speed wireless communication. Wireless Terabit-per-second (Tbps) links are expected to become a reality within the next ten years. Towards this aim, Terahertz Band (0.1-10 THz) communication is envisioned as one of the key wireless technologies of the next decade. These very high bit-rates will enable a plethora of long-awaited applications, such as ultra-fast massive data transfers among nearby devices, or high-definition videoconferencing among mobile personal devices in small cells. In addition, THz Band communication will also address the spectrum scarcity and capacity limitations of current cellular systems. The research objective of the project is to establish the foundations of ultra-broadband communication networks in the THz Band.

The targeted breakthrough is to drastically increase the capacity of wireless systems by two orders of magnitude by enabling the communication over the THz spectrum band, which also addresses the impending spectrum scarcity problem. In this final report, we detail the research work resulting from the collaboration among the TeraNets team members. In particular, this report focuses on:

1) Graphene-based transceivers design,

2) Ultra-broadband graphene-based antenna systems development,

3) Multi-path channel modeling and wideband characterization,

4) Three-dimensional end-to-end modeling and analysis,

5) Pulse-based modulation and channel access scheme development,

6) Multi-wideband pulse waveform design for distance adaptive wireless systems,

7) Distance-aware multi-carrier adaptive modulation scheme study,

8) Energy-efficient system design with antenna arrays,

9) Antenna-subarray-based transmission design and analysis,

10) Timing acquisition algorithms,

11) Pulse-level beam-switching MAC design with energy control (TRPLE),

12) Optimization of inter-pulse separation and inter-symbol separation in TRPLE.

These new findings within the TeraNets project have greatly increased our knowledge of both theoretical and practical aspects in THz Band communication networks. The outcomes from the TeraNets project bring us one step closer towards the realization of ultra-broadband communication networks in the THz Band. For the broader impact of the project, the research results will be incorporated into the Information and Network Theory and Wireless Communication and Networks within the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, at the Georgia Institute of Technology, both at undergraduate and graduate levels. 3 PhD students will be involved and trained to be- come experts in this fast evolving field. Master students will solve specific sub-problems within the project. The research results will be disseminated in first-rate scientific conferences, journals and premier magazines of the field.
